-- public.healthcare definition

-- Drop table

DROP TABLE public.healthcare;

CREATE TABLE public.healthcare (
	reviewdatetime text NULL,
	ratingoverall int4 NULL,
	ratingceo text NULL,
	ratingbusinessoutlook text NULL,
	ratingworklifebalance int4 NULL,
	ratingcultureandvalues int4 NULL,
	ratingdiversityandinclusion int4 NULL,
	ratingseniorleadership int4 NULL,
	ratingrecommendtofriend text NULL,
	ratingcareeropportunities int4 NULL,
	ratingcompensationandbenefits int4 NULL,
	employer text NULL,
	iscurrentjob int4 NULL,
	lengthofemployment int4 NULL,
	employmentstatus text NULL,
	jobendingyear int4 NULL,
	jobtitle text NULL,
	"location" text NULL,
	pros text NULL,
	cons text NULL,
	summary text NULL,
	advice text NULL,
	feedback text NULL,
	polarity_score float8 NULL,
	feedback_pos text NULL,
	feedback_neg text NULL
);

	 ('2019-03-25T04:50:15.387',4,'DISAPPROVE','NEUTRAL',1,3,0,1,'POSITIVE',5,5,'Mayo Clinic',0,20,'REGULAR',2016,'ICU Nurse','Los Angeles, California','I loved working with patients on the phone especially since I had 5 years of previous scheduling experience working at the Hospital and ED discharge desk.  I worked for the next 5 years at the Arrowhead Family Medicine office.','Unfortunately, my husband passed away unexpectedly in June of 2015.  This same Friday, my supervisor of 5 years relinquished the Arrowhead site to a former Supervisor who chose to write me up for all my tardies and/or absences that my former Supervisor worked with me on.  I took 5 1/2 months off on personal leave to attend to my 2 children who at the time were 13, and 17.  Additionally, I had my disabled parent living with me and for whom I needed to take care of as well.   After returning to work in January of 2016, and attending the funeral of my mother-in-law.  I was immediately reminded that I was on my first written warning and that any further tardies or absences would not be tolerated.  In August, 2016, my daughter returned to school to start her first year in high school.  She missed her ride and I had to take her to school and sign her in. Upon arrival, my supervisor, Linda Hallett, glared at me and I knew it would probably be my last day.  I workded the entire day that Friday.  At 4:45pm, she called me into her office to terminate me, she put her hands on me and tried to make me sit down to offer me some "resources".  She fired me 10 years to my service month, knowing that not only did I lose my husband, but I lost my mother-in-law in December 2015, My cousin in March of 2016 and My father in law in July 2016.  My daughter was suicidal for the first 6 months after her father died and my 17 year old son did not speak about his father for almost 2 years.  She never gave me credit for the great accomplishments I did achieve in my 10 years with Mayo Clinic and, ironically, she retired 6 weeks after terminating my employment and to top it off...she made me ineligible for re-hire.','The Needs of the patient are the only needs to considered...unless you are an employee".','Perhaps administration should  be as committed to their employees as they are to their patients and their mission statement...."The needs of the patient are the only needs to be considered".    I was an employee but I was also a "patient at Mayo Clinic".  It has taken me 3 and half years to get back on my feet and prior to working as an appointment specialist for 10 years, I was also a Licensed Practical Nurse.  I was financially, spiritually, and immorally treated by this person but no one seemed to be able to intervene on my behalf.  I suffered greatly and my career was ruined, all because of a new supervisor who, for whatever reason, had  compassion for my situation.  I spoke to everyone and every department begging for some kind of assistance.  I attended employee counseling for grief management.  This supervisor''s name was Linda Hallett.  She resigned 6 weeks after my termination but made my working environment  anything but pleasant, but exceptionally stressful on top of the stressors in my personal life.  She was relentless.  I hope that Mayo Clinic will read this documentation and remember that we are all employees with a single common goal...to help our patients, even if they are also employees.  One day...I hope to return to  Mayo Clinic, however, I am sure it will be very difficult as I have been labeled "ineligible for re-hire" by a very nasty, heartless former supervisor who was able to retire weeks after this event.  I pray I have the strength and the spirit to intervene on behalf of any person I may encounter to whom is up against an impossible to survive situation from a person in a position to "take or giveth" the benefits of working for 10 years with plans to retire with all the benefits that they worked so hard to attain. God Bless the doctors, nurses and all the medical staff who support them.  They are amazing.  Unfortunately, Administration lacks the convictions of those of us who are health care professionals, patients, and just ordinary people as well.','I loved working with patients on the phone especially since I had 5 years of previous scheduling experience working at the Hospital and ED discharge desk. This same Friday, my supervisor of 5 years relinquished the Arrowhead site to a former Supervisor who chose to write me up for all my tardies and/or absences that my former Supervisor worked with me on.  I took 5 1/2 months off on personal leave to attend to my 2 children who at the time were 13, and 17.  Additionally, I had my disabled parent living with me and for whom I needed to take care of as well.   After returning to work in January of 2016, and attending the funeral of my mother-in-law.  I was immediately reminded that I was on my first written warning and that any further tardies or absences would not be tolerated. Upon arrival, my supervisor, Linda Hallett, glared at me and I knew it would probably be my last day.  I workded the entire day that Friday.  At 4:45pm, she called me into her office to terminate me, she put her hands on me and tried to make me sit down to offer me some "resources".  She fired me 10 years to my service month, knowing that not only did I lose my husband, but I lost my mother-in-law in December 2015, My cousin in March of 2016 and My father in law in July 2016.  My daughter was suicidal for the first 6 months after her father died and my 17 year old son did not speak about his father for almost 2 years. Consultants here are the Staff doctors, and most of them 98% walk with their noses up in the air never acknowledging the nurses who care for their patients. Rochester is a very safe, small, no traffic kind of town. If you have kids, this is the place you can appreciate living in. If you are single, don''t get your hopes up.','No Parking for new staff. If you work a 7A shift, you basically have to wake up at 5A to get here on time, and that''s only if you live in TOWN!!! No diversity what so ever, and Minnesotan Nice is not nice at all! Too many two faced people here. I''m not saying that there aren’t any hypocrites anywhere else, but nothing like this place! A very bureaucratic management and advancement opportunities for nurses are limited. It certainly is about who you know and how well you''ve gotten along with your nurse manager to move up the ladder. If you''ve never worked anywhere else but Mayo you will not feel competent to work anywhere else after working here. Nurses don''t start IV, or even put foley cathers in! They have a "team" for all of this. At first this may seem nice for you that you don''t have to worry about doing this, but when you need an IV STAT, good luck! They give you less patients to care fore than other hospitals, but you will be doing a lot more than your nursing role to make up for that. Nurses here change linens, bathe your patients in a shower not just in bed, feed your patients and do your strict I&O, and sometimes get paid to sit in a combative patient''s room as a one to one, because they don''t have patient sitters here. Oh and to top it off, you''ll also be a social worker calling Nursing homes to hold patient''s bed and arrange home health Oxygen and so forth. Basically, they call this "Primary Nursing." The pay is good for the area, but not nearly enough for the job being done and the high expectations placed on patient care employees.','politics, favoritism, micromanaging, budget cuts, scheduling, burnout_x000d_
_x000d_
The obnoxious understaffing (on purpose) has caused even faster burnout on employees and with strict rules, everyone has quickly become unhappy. They say you get 10 sick days per year, but really you get corrective action beginning with 6. Any corrective action results in held pay increases, no tuition reimbursement for a year, and other big incentives. Minor corrective action receives the same penalties as a major one. There has become no incentive to stay with the company anymore. The scheduling used to work well for students (seeing that probably half of departments are students pursuing education or continuing education that''s required) but doesn''t anymore and has been increasingly frustrating. _x000d_
Many management positions have been given to people based on who they know not their credentials. This causes a lot of upset for people who have worked hard for their higher education and strong credentials but not given a position because someone has a connection to upper management.','inpatient/patient care','Care about your employees like you used to. Raises have been held, yet the salaried employees didn''t have to take a cut. Positions aren''t being filled when someone leaves, instead putting more stress on the departments. Hours were cut back, there''s continuously understaffed units, done on purpose. They say their priority is patient care, yet they compromise safety by not properly staffing units just to save a few dollars. It''s ridiculous how downhill this company has gone in just 2017 alone. Treat your staff and patients the way you did even a year ago, and maybe the turnover wouldn''t be so high. 	 ('2022-05-24T20:11:04.240',4,'NO_OPINION','POSITIVE',3,5,4,3,'POSITIVE',5,2,'HCA Healthcare',1,6,'REGULAR',NULL,'ICU Nurse','Austin, Texas','Great company culture at the corporate office. 
I''ve always felt supported and encouraged to take advantage of HCA''s resources (Harvard ManageMentor training, tuition reimbursement, etc.) and there is opportunity to move around to different service lines. 
Health insurance costs are very low for non-smokers and ability to customize or opt out for dental and vision. 
My department and manager is very flexible and trusts me to manage my workload and deadlines within reason so I can run a quick errand or go to an appt during the week as long as I''m getting my work done.

First few years here, I was in love but the rose colored glasses have been lifted and I''m hoping leadership will take the time to right the ship for the people that keep it moving.','High points: 
- There is no actual maternity leave policy - Don''t let anyone fool you, it doesn''t exist in the policy bank. There is 2 weeks "parental leave" and short-term disability that is good until your Dr clears you (around 6 wks postpartum) plus you have to use a 40 hr elimination period before you can utilize this. If you don''t have the PTO banked, it is taken unpaid. So you can piecemeal about 8 weeks together and hope you can accrue enough PTO. The third party disability company is terrible.
- Salary is NOT COMPETITIVE and has not stayed current with a changing work environment and inflation. Cost of living has gone up so much in Nashville that market base rate for my job is about $40k higher than what I''m paid. 
-Internal employees are paid far less than new hires in the same role due to annual merit pay policies (or lack thereof) and wages are capped around a 13% increase from base for promotions, even if the job was graded out much higher than that (meaning, an external candidate applying for the same role would have a much higher salary offer than an internal candidate being promoted).

The pandemic brought to light a very outdated and non-progressive side of senior leadership and the board. Most departments are back in the office 5 days a week, it feels like priority is given to our stock price, not our clinical staff or resource needs - people or otherwise (when I started, we were trading around $72/share. Things have changed since the jump to $200+). I completely understand the budget and business management aspect of missing earnings, but it is a little tone deaf to earn as much money as the company did in Q1 then engage in cost cutting measures when our hospitals/clinicians are still reeling from COVID and need our support more than ever. We''re facing physician and nursing shortages everywhere, yet still cutting resources then trying to recruit. It makes zero sense.
Since the quarterly earnings weren''t what leadership expected and the stock price dropped, some divisions have started laying off staff as part of a "back to budget" initiative even though the company was still profitable.','Great but room for improvement','We shouldn''t be letting valuable talent go when the labor market is already a problem and will cost the company far more money in the long run. Retention is ALOT cheaper than recruitment and training.

Leaning out teams/resources is just going to lead to burnout and we have too much great talent leaving for Amazon and Oracle already.','Great company culture at the corporate office. 
I''ve always felt supported and encouraged to take advantage of HCA''s resources (Harvard ManageMentor training, tuition reimbursement, etc.) and there is opportunity to move around to different service lines. 
Health insurance costs are very low for non-smokers and ability to customize or opt out for dental and vision. 
My department and manager is very flexible and trusts me to manage my workload and deadlines within reason so I can run a quick errand or go to an appt during the week as long as I''m getting my work done.

First few years here, I was in love but the rose colored glasses have been lifted and I''m hoping leadership will take the time to right the ship for the people that keep it moving.. High points: 
- There is no actual maternity leave policy - Don''t let anyone fool you, it doesn''t exist in the policy bank. There is 2 weeks "parental leave" and short-term disability that is good until your Dr clears you (around 6 wks postpartum) plus you have to use a 40 hr elimination period before you can utilize this. If you don''t have the PTO banked, it is taken unpaid. So you can piecemeal about 8 weeks together and hope you can accrue enough PTO. The third party disability company is terrible.
- Salary is NOT COMPETITIVE and has not stayed current with a changing work environment and inflation. Cost of living has gone up so much in Nashville that market base rate for my job is about $40k higher than what I''m paid. 
-Internal employees are paid far less than new hires in the same role due to annual merit pay policies (or lack thereof) and wages are capped around a 13% increase from base for promotions, even if the job was graded out much higher than that (meaning, an external candidate applying for the same role would have a much higher salary offer than an internal candidate being promoted).

The pandemic brought to light a very outdated and non-progressive side of senior leadership and the board. Most departments are back in the office 5 days a week, it feels like priority is given to our stock price, not our clinical staff or resource needs - people or otherwise (when I started, we were trading around $72/share. Things have changed since the jump to $200+). I completely understand the budget and business management aspect of missing earnings, but it is a little tone deaf to earn as much money as the company did in Q1 then engage in cost cutting measures when our hospitals/clinicians are still reeling from COVID and need our support more than ever. We''re facing physician and nursing shortages everywhere, yet still cutting resources then trying to recruit. It makes zero sense.

	 ('2016-06-20T18:55:57.953',3,'APPROVE','POSITIVE',0,3,0,4,'POSITIVE',3,4,'Mayo Clinic',1,4,'REGULAR',NULL,'Labor and Delivery Nurse','Miami,  Florida','Mayo Clinic Rochester has consistently ranked the #1 and #2 hospital in the nation. The other clinics carry the name brand and try to deliver a comparable degree of health care service. _x000d_
I suppose Mayo is generally selective with their applicants, so most of the time, you will get very bright, competent staff, ie, your management and co-workers. I have had a varied experience here. It really depends on the people, like any place. But overall, Mayo staff seem committed to quality work. My one complaint would be the office culture in certain places. Just certain things, not all. People can be unprofessional or treat their work as a social hangout. : I had a co-worker who complained and bad-mouthed the patients every two minutes, which is understandable sometimes, but, all the time? It''s so bad for morale. The bulk of people are pretty polite and kind, though. They do their job sufficiently enough. The doctors really care about their patients. _x000d_
_x000d_
Other pros:_x000d_
403b_x000d_
Health_x000d_
Dental_x000d_
Vision_x000d_
Continuing Education Courses offered online/on-site - You can schedule these into the workday_x000d_
Benefits University sessions are offered every enrollment season_x000d_
Tuition Reimbursement - I hear this is mainly to go towards positions Mayo has a serious need for_x000d_
Beautiful, well-maintained campus_x000d_
Cafeteria food is A+. There is create your own stir fry Tuesdays and pasta bar Wednesdays_x000d_
Great starting positions open up every year with chances for upward mobility_x000d_
Chapel - Catholic _x000d_
Meditation Room_x000d_
Ticket discounts for Jacksonville Symphony and other attractions_x000d_
Various employee discounts including cell phone carrier & gym memberships','Office gossip, co-workers complained, patients expectations unreasonable due to the "Mayo" brand experience - can''t make immediate appointments for services, long wait times, this is a popular hospital','Jacksonville, FL','Management addresses anticipated workplace issues in line national news,  through required required education for topics like evacuations and threats. That is something I really like._x000d_
_x000d_
The company also strives to create an idealistic company culture centered on the patient. Sometimes though, I don''t think people take the campaigns too seriously. The newsletter has a very touchy-feely pat on the back tone. I think things should just be simply stated and sincerely._x000d_
_x000d_
Also, Mayo is becoming a very productivity driven company, packing in appointments and enforcing high quotas in departments company-wide. I feel this decreases quality based on the principle that, if you''re working faster, you''ll be prone to making more errors and potentially have less quality time per patient case. I think there should be some flexibility to allow for fine quality, where there needs to be. Or more providers and workers to distribute the work load.','Mayo Clinic Rochester has consistently ranked the #1 and #2 hospital in the nation. The other clinics carry the name brand and try to deliver a comparable degree of health care service. _x000d_
I suppose Mayo is generally selective with their applicants, so most of the time, you will get very bright, competent staff, ie, your management and co-workers. I have had a varied experience here. It really depends on the people, like any place. But overall, Mayo staff seem committed to quality work. My one complaint would be the office culture in certain places. Just certain things, not all. People can be unprofessional or treat their work as a social hangout. : I had a co-worker who complained and bad-mouthed the patients every two minutes, which is understandable sometimes, but, all the time? It''s so bad for morale. The bulk of people are pretty polite and kind, though. They do their job sufficiently enough. The doctors really care about their patients. _x000d_

It seems the accepted path is to be hired in at full-time, prove oneself, then ask for a reduction to part-time. 	 ('2014-10-07T10:09:46.840',5,'APPROVE','NEUTRAL',0,5,0,5,'POSITIVE',4,4,'Mayo Clinic',1,20,'REGULAR',NULL,'Interventional Radiology Nurse','New York City, New York','I have been at Mayo Clinic since the early 2000s, and it''s the only major institution I''ve worked in, though I have had other part time positions elsewhere. I didn''t realize how good I had it for the first few years until I started to realize how hard it is to get in to a company like this, especially in economic hard times. I now work in a teleworking position and actually live out of state, even though I started out on the Rochester campus downtown. Working from home has improved my job satisfaction immensely, even though there are sometimes technical difficulties, being able to avoid commuting and having to buy work clothes makes up for the periodic inconvenience. Mayo does take good care of their employees; though, just like any large company, some work units have better supervisors and policies than other. Overall, though, they try to keep things fair in terms of compensation and hours, including systematic raises and pay ranges.','There are often "hiring freezes" in which, in order to save money, when someone leaves, they are not replaced except for in rare circumstances. Our work unit has experienced this several times now, and the work continues to be redistributed, sometimes stretching people beyond their limits, even if temporarily. The past few years, there have been a lot of campaigns to "work differently," meaning finding ways to work more efficiently and using less resources, waste, etc. It has made a big difference in a positive way in many areas; and, in the current job market, many of us who are still working, we are grateful to have a job with good benefits--however, some of the uncertainty is a little unsettling for some work groups who are always wondering if they will be next on the chopping block. For the most part, however, if a team is eliminated, those folks get first priority in placement in other departments.','Proud to work for Mayo','','I have been at Mayo Clinic since the early 2000s, and it''s the only major institution I''ve worked in, though I have had other part time positions elsewhere. I didn''t realize how good I had it for the first few years until I started to realize how hard it is to get in to a company like this, especially in economic hard times. I now work in a teleworking position and actually live out of state, even though I started out on the Rochester campus downtown. Working from home has improved my job satisfaction immensely, even though there are sometimes technical difficulties, being able to avoid commuting and having to buy work clothes makes up for the periodic inconvenience. Mayo does take good care of their employees; though, just like any large company, some work units have better supervisors and policies than other. Overall, though, they try to keep things fair in terms of compensation and hours, including systematic raises and pay ranges.. There are often "hiring freezes" in which, in order to save money, when someone leaves, they are not replaced except for in rare circumstances. Our work unit has experienced this several times now, and the work continues to be redistributed, sometimes stretching people beyond their limits, even if temporarily. The past few years, there have been a lot of campaigns to "work differently," meaning finding ways to work more efficiently and using less resources, waste, etc. It has made a big difference in a positive way in many areas; and, in the current job market, many of us who are still working, we are grateful to have a job with good benefits--however, some of the uncertainty is a little unsettling for some work groups who are always wondering if they will be next on the chopping block. For the most part, however, if a team is eliminated, those folks get first priority in placement in other departments.',4.90025,'mayo clinic early major institution worked time position realize good year started realize hard company like especially economic hard time work teleworking position actually live state started rochester campus downtown working home improved job satisfaction immensely technical difficulty able avoid commuting buy work clothes make periodic inconvenience mayo good care employee like large company work unit better supervisor policy overall try thing fair term compensation hour including systematic raise pay range hiring freeze order save money leaf replaced rare circumstance work unit experienced time work continues redistributed stretching people limit temporarily past year lot campaign work differently meaning finding way work efficiently resource waste etc big difference positive way area current job market working grateful job good benefit uncertainty little unsettling work group wondering chopping block team eliminated folk priority placement department',NULL),

	 ('2014-08-04T06:31:35.293',4,'NO_OPINION','NEUTRAL',5,4,0,3,'POSITIVE',4,4,'Mayo Clinic',1,6,'REGULAR',NULL,'ICU Nurse','Sun City,   Florida','The best thing about Mayo is that everyone(well, almost everyone) really does realize that the needs of our patients come first, regardless of what time of the night or weekend it is. _x000d_
_x000d_
That being said, working at Mayo in IT is mostly an 8-5 job. The reason for this is that there is not enough parking downtown, so at 5:00 pm there is a max exodus of employees trying to catch their bus ride home. There is an on-call rotation, however, so  I can be paged in the middle of the night if a system has a problem. _x000d_
_x000d_
Management is good, and I happen to work right now for an exceptional manager. _x000d_
_x000d_
Salary and benefits are excellent, even though old timers grumble about the "good old days" where healthcare premiums were covered free of charge.','IT at Mayo is what I would charitably call "mass controlled chaos". Doctors have a lot of power at Mayo, so in the past, if a doctor wanted a pet project, she usually got it. Regardless of whether it required special databases, middleware, etc. _x000d_
_x000d_
Because of this, Mayo is rife with one-off applications, environments and technologies all over the place. Until recently, it was a free-for-all where almost anything goes. _x000d_
_x000d_
Finally, Mayo brought in a new CIO who is working towards streamlining IT and attempting to introduce standardization. It''s a slow process, but we have seen some positive changes already. Still lots of work to do in this area. _x000d_
_x000d_
Work/life balance is very good, but Mayo is a bit conservative, so there is not the flexibility like there is at other companies like IBM. You''re pretty much expected to be in the office from 8-5. _x000d_
_x000d_
Parking in downtown Rochester is abysmal for Mayo employees. I think the current waiting list for a parking spot is about 12 years. Most employees park at "Park & Rides" and take the bus into downtown.','Great place to work!','Mayo needs to continue to try to reduce the number of differing technologies in its infrastructure. _x000d_

	 ('2022-07-15T11:23:18.810',3,'DISAPPROVE','POSITIVE',3,3,4,2,'POSITIVE',4,3,'HCA Healthcare',0,6,'REGULAR',2021,'Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN)','Sanford,   Florida','This is a very high profile company to have on your resume, especially if you''re in the Nashville area market. I loved the work-life balance I had in my department most of the time. My colleagues were great folks that cared about me personally and professionally. The employee stock purchase program (purchasing HCA stock at a 10% discount) was nice. I also loved that they gave you 4 paid days per year to volunteer. Corporate facilities are nice, main Park Plaza HQ was renovated throughout 2015-2018.','For me, the pandemic unveiled a lot of problematic things with this company. Corporate employees took a 10-20% pay cut during Q2 2020. In November of 2020, they gave us a "bonus" for 50% of the amount that we weren''t paid, but we never saw the other 50% (they''re probably hoping we forgot.. we didn''t) meanwhile they continued to be super profitable. For a couple of years, quarter close fell on a weekend and just when we thought we were done with that, they moved close up a day, effectively creating another year of the weekend problem. PTO policy is quite stingy - you only accrue 8.67 hours per month your first 5 years of employment.. and that''s your vacation AND sick time, in one PTO bucket. In July of 2021, they required us to be in office at least 3 days per week with little flexibility. (And I have heard since leaving that they''re making most people be in office 5 days per week unless you can get "approved" for 1 WFH day.) The organizational structure is very layered and hierarchical. While I mostly loved my department managers, in hindsight, I was micromanaged quite extensively compared to where I am now. I don''t think it''s personally their fault; it''s just the company culture. They gave me BS reasons for not getting promoted, so I got my promotion elsewhere, along with a 60% compensation increase. The pay at HCA is simply not as competitive as it once was.','Not the company it used to be','Hybrid work is the way of the future,  whether you like it or not. Until you become less old fashioned and out of touch, and pay employees what they''re worth, you''re going to continue to have somewhat of a revolving door. 2. Protect Whistle blowers and fix the problems they uncover.  There are only so many things that can be swept under the rug until external agencies will notice._x000d_
_x000d_
3. Eradicate toxic work environments._x000d_
_x000d_
4. Instill into management that employees are patients, not nameless peons, and should be treated with respect._x000d_
_x000d_
5. Spend less time covering up breaches and issues and more time preventing them from happening.','- Mayo collects some extremely talented staff._x000d_
_x000d_

_x000d_

	 ('2022-08-12T08:07:16.217',1,'DISAPPROVE','NEGATIVE',5,1,2,1,'NEGATIVE',1,4,'HCA Healthcare',0,2,'REGULAR',2022,'Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN)','Sun City,   Florida','Benefits are good. _x000D_

My equipment was nice._x000D_
OT pay is really good if you don''t mind suffering through 10-15 hour days. Plus you get to choose when and at what time you want to do OT.','Besides those things I mentioned above, literally everything. EVERYTHING._x000D_
I couldn''t imagine ever wanting to work here again, and I''m surprised I lasted as long as I did. Leaving was the most freeing experience. Onboarding and training made it seem like you were in a really relaxed, nice work environment. But once those few weeks were up in training, you were thrown into a snake pit. Satan handles Hell better than this place. Workplace politics and gossip were suffocating, everything is so unbelievably corporate (and while that wouldnt necessarily be a bad thing, the standardization makes it difficult to even suggest any new ideas or branch out to benefit your department or area), and the company expects you to make your life HCA. Not at work, mind you. I mean your ENTIRE life. Holidays, gone. Weekends, gone. Spending time with family and friends....Why do you need them when you have HCA, right? There is no work life balance, and upper management is useless. They only seem to come around immediately when you mess up or when they need something done, but if you need anything, expect to wait forever for the smallest of answers. One on ones with management is always a gamble because I consistently felt like any day was just going to be my last, even when I didn''t do anything to really warrant that. HCA really isn''t worth it. You could find a better and healthier place to work.','If you like to suffer you will love HCA','One time the whole department got an email practically saying that we weren''t doing enough and that we needed to take on extra work, even though they put a hold on hiring people and just milked their employees dry and let the employees suffer through burn out. _x000D_

"Mayo Clinic" was a disappointment to my high expectations of premium benefits, pay and treatment as a nurse as they can be the best for their patients, but not their staff.','Just meh...','It''s really passive for the answer to always be "we''re utilizing all of the tools in our toolbox to do the best that we can" when literally any kind of concern is brought up, especially related to nurse''s lives - pay, benefits, time off, getting that time off, scheduling, bonus pay..... You know how many times I saw and heard something along the lines of "Mayo Clinic conducts regular market analysis and remains completive with salary and benefits packages in the geographical location..." Mayo Clinic, in it''s almighty name and reputation, should be SETTING the bar instead of claiming it is competitive with it. That''s like saying we''ll work as hard as everyone else in the group but we have the IQ score of 300 so we''ll "dumb" ourselves down to meet everyone else. Be the Bar. Set the Score. You can be better for your nurses Mayo. Especially after these past two years. Spread the wealth and benefits to your frontline crews and stop being greedy at the tippy top! We don''t want pizza parties and ice cream, we want wage increases, more vacation and better benefits! We want to know you care about us in a more solid and concrete way and not the very passive, uncaring, step dad way who throws a band aid of courage out every time we cry. _x000D_
Also, sick time and paid vacation time should be separate banks. It''s absolutely not right that I would have to use my earned "vacation time" if I should get sick and need to call into work preventing me from taking that actual and well deserved vacation later in the year because I got sick. 	 ('2022-02-08T19:18:12.320',2,'NO_OPINION','NEGATIVE',2,1,1,1,'NEGATIVE',3,2,'Mayo Clinic',1,0,'REGULAR',NULL,'Interventional Radiology Nurse','Las Vegas, Nevada','At one point if you change departments you are allowed to keep your pay or have your pay increase based on your new department pay rate. You can sign up for leadership training with the approval of your supervisor( this does not guarantee any results of having a possible role in leadership).','So I''ve been there for quite a few years and it seems to be getting rapidly worse. I''ve seen a lot of abuse of power and covering up as well as retaliation. There are constant threats to terminate people for what is turning out to be any reason. Poor communication. Constant policy changes almost weekly to daily and you''re penalized if you do not know these. New hires with little to no experience are being offered higher pay than the current employees that have been there for years. People who apply for one of the Mayo clinics other sites and are hired for the said site but physically sit in another state are NOT being paid the posted compensation on the positions they applied for because they live in another state. Benefits are not the best at all (pricing and coverage details vary depending on which department you work for). You are treated as if you are a child (For example : The "Stars" kids get elementary, an almost exact replica and each "star" means something different) but instead of stars, you get coupons. For Medical Leave, you are only allowed to make up 3 days per quarter (even if your department is still actively working and during business hours they will not allow you to make up the hours ( as if the individual can control whatever medical issues or treatments are required for them; this also varies as to which department you work for. I have learned that you are not allowed to share information with your colleagues even if you think that could keep them out of trouble or things that you guys just may disagree with and may have general questions about. My coworker is a private person and she tried to add her husband to her insurance and their response to her was; pretty much, well you never talked about your husband or mentioned that you had a husband before so we''re going to need your marriage certificate as proof. I have been in meetings where supervisors have told several of my coworkers who had general concerns that they should be grateful that they even have a job because of everything that''s going on. In addition, the major issue that''s happening is if you happen to be on the call or an assignment that runs over or into you''re 15 minutes or your lunch, they are implementing rules that if you don''t get off on time or you don''t log out on time then you completely miss your break and or you only get to use what''s left of it (Meaning if you are on a call that runs 5 minutes into your break you only get 10 minutes left of a break or they''ll tell you you''re not allowed to take your break at all. The same thing for your lunch. If you are on a call and the call runs 10 to 20 minutes into your lunch you are only allowed to take a 50 or 40-minute lunch instead of a full-hour lunch). Everything you do is timed. Everything. More responsibilities are being added without additional allowed time. So if you get a patient or a client who is just so confused and has a lot of questions you only have 4.5 minutes to answer their questions and if it goes over that you are in trouble. You''re rushing them off the phone and leaving more questions than answers and you have 3 minutes to note the call in said person''s account anything over and your score suffers drastically and threats of termination role in. There is a lot of writing off the wealthy''s debt and sending people who are struggling financially and health-wise to collections. It is a very stressful environment. A large number of my team members have announced that they are seeking employment elsewhere. Everything I have mentioned has been spoken out to leadership and though they stated they were going to look into it there have been zero results yet and it has been 2 years of decline. The only response we received is that there will be no active changes in regards to anything I''ve mentioned above.','Door opener- not career',NULL,'At one point if you change departments you are allowed to keep your pay or have your pay increase based on your new department pay rate. Everything you do is timed. Everything. More responsibilities are being added without additional allowed time. 	 ('2018-04-20T11:09:00.773',3,'NO_OPINION','NEUTRAL',7,2,0,2,'NEGATIVE',3,3,'Mayo Clinic',0,4,'REGULAR',2017,'Advanced Practice Registered Nurse','Miami,  Florida','Mayo Clinic is well known. Great employee gym. Facilities are quite good, lots of cutting-edge medicine is done.  Career opportunities are great in some areas.','Mayo is still remarkably old-fashioned. This can be great for many people in many roles, but can make it an uphill battle for career-minded women to be recognized for your work. The organization is still rather centered around male doctors with stay-at-home-wives... i.e., gym childcare hours, appropriate benefits, lack of sufficient breast pumping rooms in work areas, and lack of formal maternity leave  support the men + stay-at-home-wives well, but start leaving working women feeling unsupported or valued. This is particularly true for women with non-traditional-female careers, such as research. Finally, several women I personally know have run into pure sexism with certain bosses. Sexist jokes about women always spending your hard-earned money that you''re expected to laugh at, being told that it looks impossible to make it in research if you decide as a woman to have kids (though men can be parents just fine), and holding maternity leave personally against someone is ridiculous. Beyond that, it took years for HR to finally deal with a research PI who held lab meetings that somehow women are never invited to, took womens'' names off of research papers they authored (typically without telling them) and assigned highly technically qualified women basic lab maintenance roles that men are magically exempt from. Why are these types of behaviour tolerated by Mayo culture?','Experience is highly dependent on what you do and your boss','Get up to date when it comes to supporting the female half of your staff. You can''t honestly say that you''re equal opportunity on paper, and then only offer childcare at the gym from noon to 2 pm on weekdays when working moms can never take advantage of it. Not to mention allowing blatantly sexist behaviors to continue, particularly in research. The fact that particular PIs bring in a lot of research money isn''t good justification to allow them to continue such behaviors. Oh, and postdocs and research techs are people too, with valuable skillsets. Please give us livable pay and benefits for the long hours we put into the research that helps keep Mayo''s name strong!','Mayo Clinic is well known. Great employee gym. Facilities are quite good, lots of cutting-edge medicine is done.  Career opportunities are great in some areas.. Mayo is still remarkably old-fashioned. This can be great for many people in many roles, but can make it an uphill battle for career-minded women to be recognized for your work. The organization is still rather centered around male doctors with stay-at-home-wives... i.e., gym childcare hours, appropriate benefits, lack of sufficient breast pumping rooms in work areas, and lack of formal maternity leave  support the men + stay-at-home-wives well, but start leaving working women feeling unsupported or valued. This is particularly true for women with non-traditional-female careers, such as research. Finally, several women I personally know have run into pure sexism with certain bosses. Sexist jokes about women always spending your hard-earned money that you''re expected to laugh at, being told that it looks impossible to make it in research if you decide as a woman to have kids (though men can be parents just fine), and holding maternity leave personally against someone is ridiculous. Beyond that, it took years for HR to finally deal with a research PI who held lab meetings that somehow women are never invited to, took womens'' names off of research papers they authored (typically without telling them) and assigned highly technically qualified women basic lab maintenance roles that men are magically exempt from. 	 ('2010-09-19T05:45:37.543',3,'DISAPPROVE','',6,0,0,3,'NEGATIVE',2,2,'Mayo Clinic',0,0,'',2009,'ICU Nurse','Dallas, Texas','I worked in the Birdsall Research institute, one of the research arms of Mayo Clinic Jacksonville, for 13 years, from 1996-2009. It  had attracted some outstanding scientists, and had an well-deserved reputation for excellent research, especially in genetics and brain diseases, good for building a pedigree for a young scientist. They have some very good resources for pathology and genetics, and for a small institute, the scientific facilities were excellent.  Pay was reasonable, but middle of the road. The health care package was excellent, medical care at the Mayo Clinic top notch. Most staffers are nice, happy people, good to work wtih;  handling of administrative matters is typically very efficient. Mayo Clinic is only about 15 minutes from the beach, so this made it nice to get away after a hard day at work.','There are  a number of serious issues with make me hesitant to encourage a young scientist,  interested in academic research, to consider working in the basic research institutes at Mayo Clinic Jacksonville, especially if they have a family and want a long-term appointment there. The Birdsall institute started to lose  its scientific luster around 2005, with the loss of most of  top notch research scientists between 2005-2010; this has left behind a shell of junior investigators and less active senior investigators. The star investigators have left for a variety of reasons, but all within the last 5 years. To top all of this off, Mayo has not been able to replace the lost staff with people of equal quality, in part because of financial cutbacks and reduced hiring incentives, but also because this insititute is quite remote; no one wants to live there. The nearest research institute of similar quality is over 90 minutes away in Gainesville.  _x000d_
_x000d_
Although branded as academic research environment,  if you are a newly minted Ph.D. looking for a comfortable university environment where you can dress down, let it all hang out, and personalize your work space, forget about it here. Mayo makes no bones about being a corporation;  they make it absolutely clear that you are part of their (corporate) Family, and expect you to adhere to all of their guidelines, ranging from dress code (one widely made fun of bulletin urged all employees to wear "color coordinated underwear") to what you can put on your desk ("No plants, family pictures, or personal items of any kind, please. We are a corporation, people, let''s keep it professional.")  _x000d_
_x000d_
As an employee, you will be  underpaid and overworked; and you get no retirement benefits whatsoever as a low level employee. If you manage to hang on for 5 years in a staff position, you become vested. (However, time spent as a postdoc is not counted toward a staff position, however; it is only after you get an academic appointment that the clock starts ticking, so you might end up with retirement benefits 7-9 years after you start working there, if you are even  favored with a promotion to an instructor.)  As a research institute within Mayo, there are a lot of soft-money positions, and PIs push most of their staff very hard; I have heard the environment likened to a "high-pressure boiler." A typical work week is 55-60 hours for a postdoc, accompanied by high pressure  to get in there and  produce from the PI. Firing can be at will, so make sure that you don''t screw up on the job or over annoy your supervisors. _x000d_
_x000d_
Looking at all of the issues,  the biggest failing of the Mayo remains the laughable promotion and management structure that is peculiar to the Institute. Management seems to be a fiefdom model (PIs are the kings, postdocs knights, and everyone else are lowly serfs), and you were expected to behave according to your station. As a new hire, If you are looking for a equitable academic meritocracy where you will be rewarded for your hard work and great ideas, or at least acknowledged here, let me disabuse you from your  illusions about this right now. Of course, not everyone behaves disreputably, but there are enough bad apples in this bunch to spoil this environment for everyone else. Although Mayo promotes itself as a meritocracy, when I worked there this was clearly not the case, and it was sad to see so many promising young scientists ground down by the unforgiving environment. Job promotion and prospects at Birdsall are governed by the recommendations of a self-appointed cabal of principal investigators who had a vested interest in subsuming power (a power clique) , most of whom have been promoted from within, some on their own merits, many not. The better faculty stayed out of this little power block, but it was a distressing experience to see this grow like a cancer  within the Institute.  One thing that became clear was that  favoritism and nepotism, rather than merits of the candidates, were the driver for the  promotion of certain individuals.   Consequently, well-liked  minted people could rise quickly through the ranks, while others who were not blessed by their betters would  get stuck early in the process, with no hope of advancement. How far your could you go up the ladder was  only modestly correlated with your productivity. Your job prospects depended upon who was  cheer-leading you. _x000d_
_x000d_
And finally, one other point about Mayo''s promotion progress is there hidden requirement that you need to be an MD to be in upper management; the MDs who run the place don''t care much at all about research (it''s not a big driver of incoming dollars, their bottom line), and have been cutting the financial underpinnings of this for the last 10 years. If you are a lowly academic, with merely a Ph.D., and you are looking for a management position, you won''t go very far; nearly all of the long-term senior management have MDs, so the odds are stacked against you if you as a basic scientist.','Not great for an academic career','Mayo administration needs stop the rampant nepotism within the division and make up their mind if they want a research program or not. As it is, the Instutite  is a mean little environment that  is out of step with Mayo''s mission to treat its employees as a "Family."  With the loss of  scientifically prominent people and budget cutbacks at the Institute, I see little reason why a newly minted postdoc should strongly consider going to an isolated branch of Mayo Clinic Jacksonville for a research career. A year or two might be OK for short-term postdoc''ing  to get your feet wet, but it''s definitely not what it used to be as a career driver for the budding scientist. if you want to make a long-term career, there are better, and more comfortable, places to hone your skills.','I worked in the Birdsall Research institute, one of the research arms of Mayo Clinic Jacksonville, for 13 years, from 1996-2009. It  had attracted some outstanding scientists, and had an well-deserved reputation for excellent research, especially in genetics and brain diseases, good for building a pedigree for a young scientist. They have some very good resources for pathology and genetics, and for a small institute, the scientific facilities were excellent.  Pay was reasonable, but middle of the road. The health care package was excellent, medical care at the Mayo Clinic top notch. Most staffers are nice, happy people, good to work wtih;  handling of administrative matters is typically very efficient. Mayo Clinic is only about 15 minutes from the beach, so this made it nice to get away after a hard day at work.. There are  a number of serious issues with make me hesitant to encourage a young scientist,  interested in academic research, to consider working in the basic research institutes at Mayo Clinic Jacksonville, especially if they have a family and want a long-term appointment there. The Birdsall institute started to lose  its scientific luster around 2005, with the loss of most of  top notch research scientists between 2005-2010; this has left behind a shell of junior investigators and less active senior investigators. The star investigators have left for a variety of reasons, but all within the last 5 years. To top all of this off, Mayo has not been able to replace the lost staff with people of equal quality, in part because of financial cutbacks and reduced hiring incentives, but also because this insititute is quite remote; no one wants to live there. The nearest research institute of similar quality is over 90 minutes away in Gainesville.  _x000d_
_x000d_

	 ('2008-06-25T23:25:30.183',3,'APPROVE','',4,0,0,3,'',3,3,'Mayo Clinic',1,0,'',NULL,'Advanced Practice Registered Nurse','Columbus, Georgia','Mayo Clinic has very good work life balance. It is very satisfying to work for a company that is clearly making a positive difference for mayo people''s lives.','Mayo, from an IT/IS perspective has some big problems and frustrations.  First, our failure rate on projects is much higher than it should be.  There are many reasons for this.   One is the strict requirements from a development point of view.  Mayo has an IT standard called the Target Technical Architecture (TTA).  The goal of the TTA is to provide a uniform, consistent IT infrastructure across this organization, a nobel goal.  But what it really does is lock us into a set of tools that is out of date, and not optimal for the problems we are trying to solve.  This makes work tedious and boring and redundant.  When you know there are better solutions, but you are not allowed to use them, it can be very demoralizing.  I think it also stifles creativity.  _x000d_
Another problem is that Mayo''s IT infrastructure lacks a good project management and testing group for IT projects. _x000d_
One of the most frustrating and demoralizing decisions recently is that all IT staff at Mayo are going to be required to wear business formal.  For many of us with no direct patient contact, this makes no sense.  It is going to make work more uncomfortable for many of us.  Its also expensive for us to have to go out and buy a fancy wardrobe.','We have the right goals, we just need to figure out how to accomplish them.','Realize that IT is central to the success of the business. The organization, management, and analysis of data at Mayo is too important to hand off to vendors. 	 ('2020-01-20T05:53:18.470',4,'APPROVE','POSITIVE',3,5,0,4,'POSITIVE',5,3,'Mayo Clinic',1,4,'REGULAR',NULL,'Advanced Practice Registered Nurse','San Antonio, Texas','Good benefits, personal access to some of the world''s best medical diagnostics, decent retirement incentives, tuition reimbursement, a fast-growing institution with $4 billion to achieve the stated goal of offering the WORLD''S best healthcare by 2030.  Great real estate appreciation in Rochester._x000d_
_x000d_
Exposed to some of the best physicians and researchers in the world, with Mayo recruiting talent from across the globe to achieve their 2030 goals._x000d_
_x000d_
2030 goals offer a lot of opportunity for career growth.','With our new CEO starting just one year ago, administration is coming out of the dark ages.  Today''s more modern leadership/management philosophies are steeped in the model of "the inspired employee".   Not so much here - this has been a very traditional top/down hierarchical system like one would commonly see 15-20 years ago._x000d_
_x000d_
However, I already see signs of moving in the right direction with our new CEO who speaks regularly about the importance of a joyful and fulfilled workforce, - championing the undeniable basis that the institution will be unable to continue offering the world''s best health care if the employees responsible for creating said health care are not joyful, fulfilled, inspired, encouraged._x000d_
_x000d_
No employee parking in Rochester.  You will need to find another way to get to work; and winters in Rochester are brutal so waiting at a bus stop is beyond miserable.  But the bus system is good; it''s clean and runs just about all over town, and Mayo pays for it._x000d_
_x000d_
I was told I would have 2 weeks of PTO first year but NOT told that I would be forced to use these for every holiday AND for every day missed due to an inability to travel (due to bad weather ie frozen streets/white out conditions).  And PTO is slow to build - it takes a few years to build enough PTO to have a decent vacation plus cover holidays plus cover bad weather days._x000d_
_x000d_
The Rochester locals, who you''ll be working with largely, are courteous, but mostly hail from many generations of farmers._x000d_
_x000d_
Extremely difficult for newcomers to build a social life.  Most locals spend their weekends with their families, and they''re generally closed-off to "outsiders"._x000d_
_x000d_
Very little direction is given to the new employee re navigating this large institution''s highways and byways.    _x000d_
_x000d_
Compensation isn''t super competitive._x000d_
_x000d_
Most employees are stressed out, with more work to do each day than they can possibly do.  But there''s a general acceptance of this so you''re likely to be "cut some slack" when you can''t get it all done - but generally, you need to find a way.  Many non salaried employees work while not clocked in so they can get it all done.  Overtime is either highly discouraged or not allowed at all - but you''re expected to get it done.','Stellar Diagnostics, Fast Growing,  but Dark Ages Administration (but doing better)','Follow your new leader as it pertains to the leadership philosophies he''s implementing, research the successes of employee leadership and inspiration set by Facebook and Google (and most all successful large institutions today).','Good benefits, personal access to some of the world''s best medical diagnostics, decent retirement incentives, tuition reimbursement, a fast-growing institution with $4 billion to achieve the stated goal of offering the WORLD''S best healthcare by 2030. 	 ('2015-02-19T06:51:49.010',2,'NO_OPINION','NEGATIVE',8,1,0,2,'NEGATIVE',1,3,'Mayo Clinic',1,6,'REGULAR',NULL,'Advanced Practice Registered Nurse','Sacramento, California','Mayo Clinic has Administrative Assistants; there are no perks to being an Administrative Assistant other than for those who are trying to enter Mayo Clinic as an employee - this is the way to get your foot in the door.','Mayo Clinic has been reevaluating a lot of job classes stemming from the Sirota Survey responses.  But the only job class/category not being reevaluated is secretarial positions.  The last change made to this job category was back in 2004 (11 years ago in March) and only a title change was made from Administrative Secretary to Administrative Assistant.  The pay range was not adjusted to reflect this change as is the case with numerous other job title changes at Mayo Clinic.  _x000d_
_x000d_
Part of the new Mayo Clinic culture is to invest in Talent as part of their Strategic Plan.  So why does Mayo Clinic not invest in the talent they already have on staff or by hiring those with specific vocational degrees and job experience instead of investing in someone with no work experience and a non-related degrees (i.e., Biblical Theology, Psychology, etc.) to perform Administrative Assistant work?  That’s the million dollar question.  Mayo Clinic sees talent as having a Bachelor''s Degree and no experience and you don''t even need to know how to spell or use proper grammar.  _x000d_
_x000d_
There are employees at Mayo Clinic who are currently doing secretarial work who have had their job title and job description changed along with a salary range increase but are still performing secretarial work.  For example, two women could be sitting in the same office performing the same job duties but, because one has a bachelor’s degree, is paid more.  To get around the federal rules the minimum qualifications are changed and/or the job description. However, a job description change does not necessarily mean that is what is being done in that job.  When employees witness such action, it is demoralizing to those who are working in the same capacity but are paid significantly less.  _x000d_
_x000d_
A lot of other job classes requiring Associate Degrees and/or Diplomas offer different steps that employees can move through in their positions; e.g., Research Protocol Specialist I, II, II & Senior, etc. For those of us who choose this as a career and have 10, 15, 20-30 years of experience in this field, we are not considered “talented” enough to be given opportunities unless we have a Bachelor’s Degree._x000d_
_x000d_
Unfortunately, for those of us who have vocational degrees/diplomas, we are not allowed to advance in our field of choice because Mayo Clinic is oppressing those of us who love this work and choose to do this work as a career choice.  For those of us who speak up, we are basically banished from ever going further in this field.  After dedicating many years of your life to Mayo Clinic as an Administrative Assistant you will eventually be capped at the top of the pay range.  At this point you will only receive the pay range increase and nothing extra.  Mayo Clinic used to give our Merit Increases to those who were at this point, but this has been done away with for the secretarial field.  All other fields get their Merit Increases by being able to advance to different levels within their job fields and by job titles being changed to make accommodations for exclusive employees to continue receiving pay increases.  In 2015, the pay range across the board increased 2% so that means those at the top of the pay range only receive a 2% increase.  Now that’s investing in your talent and investing in staff who give 1/2 their lives to an organization.','Administrative Assistants @ Mayo Clinic','Redesign the structure of all secretarial jobs at Mayo Clinic.  Do not allow hiring someone with a Bachelor''s Degrees into secretarial positions unless they have an Associate Degree or Diploma plus 2-5 years of full-time very specific secretarial work experience.  Make years of experience in the secretarial field a requirement for being qualified for a secretarial job. - The pay is competitive for the area, and the benefits are still OK.','- The IT department as a whole is poorly organized and very inefficient. Efforts to improve this are ongoing, but implementations of those improvements are extremely slow. _x000d_
- The leadership model is strange for IT. Mayo is a physician led organization, and the values of the company are very patient focused, as they should be. These values tend to cross over into IT and while there are many smart and dynamic IT leaders, they tend to be less technology focused. Most lead programmers I know were never really programmers, and are more project manager types. As result there is a lack of real technical leadership at Mayo. Depending on your perspective this is not always a bad thing. It is easier to get your way when your boss doesn''t understand the technical details of what you are doing. _x000d_

	 ('2022-06-13T16:26:17.923',4,'NO_OPINION','POSITIVE',6,5,5,2,'POSITIVE',3,3,'HCA Healthcare',1,4,'REGULAR',NULL,'ICU Nurse','New York City, New York','Great company to work for.','Not enough pay for all the work.','Great company',NULL,'Great company to work for.. 	 ('2012-09-15T23:30:08.540',2,'DISAPPROVE','NEUTRAL',8,2,0,1,'NEGATIVE',3,4,'Mayo Clinic',1,4,'REGULAR',NULL,'Advanced Practice Registered Nurse','Miami,  Florida','Mayo Clinic has many great things going for it.  You have the opportunity to work with some world class minds and equipment.  Making lateral movements within the foundation is a viable option even if it takes some time.  The compensation is geared to keep people for the long term, the benefits are reasonable (provided you receive treatment at a Mayo facility), and the fact you are associated with the Clinic in general allows many perks with insurance, discounts, etc._x000d_
_x000d_
On paper the mission statement that drives the direction of the Clinic "...the needs of the patient come first..." sounds wonderful.  The "Three Shields" concept is motivating: Practice, Education, & Research.  There are many people that are intelligent, driven, and truly do care about the direction of the medical field to enhance patient care, satisfaction, and experience.  When you find those people, hold onto them, as they are your true resource to experience the vision that the founding Mayo Brothers had._x000d_
_x000d_
While the location of Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, itself is a little boring, it has the feel of a small town with some of the conveniences of a large city, which isn''t such a bad thing if you have a family.','Mayo Clinic is a bureaucratic hell.  There is enough unnecessary red tape to suffocate any and every respirating organism on the planet.  At times getting access to equipment, funding, and personnel for clinical research can be a struggle, whereas another colleague can request the same thing and literally have it almost instantaneously.  Mayo Clinic is very much a who you know community rampant with nepotism, favoritism, and other inequities._x000d_
_x000d_
The "Mayo Mantra" is to speak up when you as an employee have comments, questions, or concerns.  This can be to your detriment given the aforementioned, and I speak of this in a completely neutral fashion.  You don''t have to be forceful, rude, or considered a "problem" to be the recipient of severe backlash should your viewpoints contradict a member of management''s or a consultant''s (doctor''s) opinion.  Suggesting something, even altruistically, can come back to bite you the higher up you go in the Foundation''s food-chain._x000d_
_x000d_
Despite encountering intelligent, driven, and compassionate individuals for every one of them there are 20 who care nothing of innovation.  People with whom I have spoken with that have been with the Clinic for decades and from my own experiences have shown there are plenty of hourly, salaried, and management staff members who care nothing more than to maintain the status quo and their paycheck.  Some individuals get away with terrorizing other employees or flat out not working regardless of how many times they are reported.  This has been observed in lower to mid level management as well.  Mediocrity can be a problem, and from what I have seen these are the people that get promoted._x000d_
_x000d_
The management system is stifling, where they have more say or pull than the scientists and consultants for whom the patients actually come to see for care.  Having multiple people with whom you report to often leads to contradiction to the point where you spend more time finding out how to navigate around these confutations to finally get to producing something valuable to the Clinic.  Do they have meetings to schedule meetings more than they should?  You bet.  Management of my department has admitted to having hour long discussions of words like "tardy."  Really?  Webster could define that in moments.  We use the private donation and visiting patient''s money for that?  More often than not people that aren''t even remotely your equivalent in experience or education level will be in charge of you, who will request you to do something that is either completely wrong or in some instances dangerous.  During your time in research you may find yourself continuously baffled as to why people that would be perfect candidates for these positions tell you that they applied for "that job" only to be turned down many times._x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo reacts like an overactive immune response to problems that could be solved with simply firing a issue employee.  Example: if one employee is constantly leaving early and reporting they are staying much later Mayo remedies this by punishing everyone to a new time keeping system.  What was once a flexible and amicably maintained perk in the interest of the patient and Clinic has now become almost completely inflexible._x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo Clinic as a whole is in some respects still living in the past and riding on its name too much.  The world is changing and Mayo''s competition is growing in aptitude at a better price point.  "Mother Mayo" seems to think she is the entire cosmos when in reality she is still a microcosm.','Would the Mayo Brothers be disappointed?  Probably.','Stop running the Foundation like it is a Soviet gulag.  Reduce the number of managers.  Let go of people that don''t work / offer a benefit to the Foundation or the patients it serves.  Stop trying to be everything to everyone.  Stick to the Foundation''s roots and what you excel at.  Realize that the healthcare industry doesn''t revolve around or necessarily want the "Mayo Way."','Mayo Clinic has many great things going for it.  You have the opportunity to work with some world class minds and equipment.  Making lateral movements within the foundation is a viable option even if it takes some time.  The compensation is geared to keep people for the long term, the benefits are reasonable (provided you receive treatment at a Mayo facility), and the fact you are associated with the Clinic in general allows many perks with insurance, discounts, etc._x000d_
_x000d_
On paper the mission statement that drives the direction of the Clinic "...the needs of the patient come first..." sounds wonderful.  The "Three Shields" concept is motivating: Practice, Education, & Research.  There are many people that are intelligent, driven, and truly do care about the direction of the medical field to enhance patient care, satisfaction, and experience.  When you find those people, hold onto them, as they are your true resource to experience the vision that the founding Mayo Brothers had._x000d_
_x000d_

	 ('2023-01-17T10:20:11.790',4,'APPROVE','POSITIVE',8,3,3,4,'POSITIVE',4,4,'Mayo Clinic',1,20,'REGULAR',NULL,'Labor and Delivery Nurse','Austin, Texas','Pension plan, hybrid remote work','Pay is not equal across different sites.','Would Recommend working for Mayo',NULL,'Pension plan, hybrid remote work. 	 ('2019-06-05T08:25:27.747',3,'DISAPPROVE','NEUTRAL',10,3,0,2,'NEGATIVE',3,4,'Mayo Clinic',0,20,'REGULAR',2019,'Interventional Radiology Nurse','Miami,   Florida','Exposure to complex clinical situations; nursing staff is invested in their role in patient care and advocacy. Fair compensation. Free CEU in-house.','Management and nursing staffing office consider nurses to be interchangeable widgets on a schedule with vacancies, constantly changing from day/night shift multiple times a week. There is no such thing as a work life balance if you are a staff nurse. There are many "staff satisfaction" surveys, though it would seem that little is done to improve the declining morale among nursing staff. _x000d_
Managers face punishment if they provide a reference for current or former employees for career or educational endeavors._x000d_
There are few other employment options in the area outside of Mayo, resulting in submission of nursing staff in order to keep jobs. Additionally, management bends employment laws to meet the needs of the company rather than protecting the employee. HR works closely with management with the goal of moving up in the company, therefore employees are not fairly represented when issues arise._x000d_
Not much opportunity to attend offered education in house that is not required for position. Management rules with an iron fist - autonomy of thought is not acceptable._x000d_
Regarding receiving health care: as an employee, you are triaged to receive appointments last, often not getting an appointment with your primary provider and being told there are no appointments on the available calendar (within 12 weeks). Unfortunately, the city this company resides in is in rural Minnesota, and they are the only available provider for the 40,000 employees and their families. Sadly, the health of employees suffers and health needs are unmet due to the poor management of health resources, rationing of care._x000d_
Average new nurse time at Mayo is approximately 18-22 months - meaning within a year new employees have already begun searching at other employers for positions.','Patient care  experience is unfound elsewhere in the world.','See above comments.','Exposure to complex clinical situations; nursing staff is invested in their role in patient care and advocacy. Fair compensation. Free CEU in-house.. Management and nursing staffing office consider nurses to be interchangeable widgets on a schedule with vacancies, constantly changing from day/night shift multiple times a week. There is no such thing as a work life balance if you are a staff nurse. There are many "staff satisfaction" surveys, though it would seem that little is done to improve the declining morale among nursing staff. _x000d_
Managers face punishment if they provide a reference for current or former employees for career or educational endeavors._x000d_
There are few other employment options in the area outside of Mayo, resulting in submission of nursing staff in order to keep jobs. Additionally, management bends employment laws to meet the needs of the company rather than protecting the employee. HR works closely with management with the goal of moving up in the company, therefore employees are not fairly represented when issues arise._x000d_
Not much opportunity to attend offered education in house that is not required for position. Management rules with an iron fist - autonomy of thought is not acceptable._x000d_
Regarding receiving health care: as an employee, you are triaged to receive appointments last, often not getting an appointment with your primary provider and being told there are no appointments on the available calendar (within 12 weeks). 	 ('2017-12-09T01:24:44.753',5,'APPROVE','POSITIVE',1,5,0,5,'POSITIVE',5,5,'Mayo Clinic',0,4,'REGULAR',2016,'ICU Nurse','Rochester, New York','Great salary, great benefits, coworkers and managers care about you and your well-being. Low turn over. They have very high standards and will support you to meet them. 	 ('2016-04-06T19:20:53.290',1,'NO_OPINION','NEGATIVE',6,2,0,1,'NEGATIVE',2,4,'Mayo Clinic',1,4,'REGULAR',NULL,'Advanced Practice Registered Nurse','San Antonio, Texas','The pay
Potential resume builder
Pension (if you really want to work here for 30 years)
I''m supposed to write 20 words, hopefully this is now enough...','PAs, as well as ARNPs, are expected to know as much as the Physicians, however are treated like we are the bottom of the totem pole. So we are good enough to do the seeing of their patients, assess, diagnose, treat, etc etc, but then when it comes to doing all the scut work, that is also our job. We are not treated with the appropriate amount of respect when it comes to anything, other than being trusted to (depended on to) do all of the patient care. But then when a patient needs to be called for a simple message (secretary or MA task), your patients vitals need to be taken (an MA task), something needs to be faxed (secretary task), a form needs to be entered in the computer (MA, CNA, or secretary task): the PA or NP is also supposed to do also do all of that. So basically, mayo sees all "APP''s" (as they like to call us) as first year residents who the Physicians can unload all of their work on to, as well as can be used for clerical and any other task that needs doing. If you are a PA or an ARNP and are thinking of joining Mayo, keep in mind you will have no ancillary staff to help you, as is the case in the rest of the non-Mayo world. You are the ancillary staff, in addition to being expected to keep a full calendar of patients. Get ready for zero respect from the physicians. If you happen to go in to a surgical subspecialty, you will be delighted to see that between getting to the hospital at 6 am to "pre-round" on all of the surgeons patients before he/she gets there (read: pretty much do everything for the surgeon while he/she is either sleeping or in the "consultants only" lounge, rounding, getting to the OR before the surgeon, doing the assisting in the case, helping at the end of the case, prepping for the next case (it is now 2:00pm), you are not allowed in the surgeons lounge. The surgeon, and whatever other consultant who may chose to also accompany him or her, is free to grab whatever free snack and water or juice and watch some TV while you hold your pee and prep for the next case. Eating? Resting? Going to the bathroom? You haven''t earned those privileges as an APP at Mayo. Oh, and by the way, you can create all the revenue you''d like with your full schedule, charging almost the same as the physician does and getting paid a quarter of that, but you are also not allowed to park in the garage. So you, Physician Assistant or Nurse Practitioner, can park out in Timbuktoo in the middle of whatever weather elements there may be and walk about a quarter of a mile a day to get to work while the physicians park in their designated spots in the garage, and get there after you do and you''ve seen their first patient.','PAs are treated like medical assistants','It''s so convoluted I don''t even know where to start. 	 ('2016-04-06T19:20:53.290',1,'NO_OPINION','NEGATIVE',7,2,0,1,'NEGATIVE',2,4,'Mayo Clinic',1,4,'REGULAR',NULL,'Labor and Delivery Nurse','Las Vegas, Nevada','The pay
Potential resume builder
Pension (if you really want to work here for 30 years)
I''m supposed to write 20 words, hopefully this is now enough...','PAs, as well as ARNPs, are expected to know as much as the Physicians, however are treated like we are the bottom of the totem pole. So we are good enough to do the seeing of their patients, assess, diagnose, treat, etc etc, but then when it comes to doing all the scut work, that is also our job. We are not treated with the appropriate amount of respect when it comes to anything, other than being trusted to (depended on to) do all of the patient care. But then when a patient needs to be called for a simple message (secretary or MA task), your patients vitals need to be taken (an MA task), something needs to be faxed (secretary task), a form needs to be entered in the computer (MA, CNA, or secretary task): the PA or NP is also supposed to do also do all of that. So basically, mayo sees all "APP''s" (as they like to call us) as first year residents who the Physicians can unload all of their work on to, as well as can be used for clerical and any other task that needs doing. If you are a PA or an ARNP and are thinking of joining Mayo, keep in mind you will have no ancillary staff to help you, as is the case in the rest of the non-Mayo world. You are the ancillary staff, in addition to being expected to keep a full calendar of patients. Get ready for zero respect from the physicians. If you happen to go in to a surgical subspecialty, you will be delighted to see that between getting to the hospital at 6 am to "pre-round" on all of the surgeons patients before he/she gets there (read: pretty much do everything for the surgeon while he/she is either sleeping or in the "consultants only" lounge, rounding, getting to the OR before the surgeon, doing the assisting in the case, helping at the end of the case, prepping for the next case (it is now 2:00pm), you are not allowed in the surgeons lounge. The surgeon, and whatever other consultant who may chose to also accompany him or her, is free to grab whatever free snack and water or juice and watch some TV while you hold your pee and prep for the next case. Eating? Resting? Going to the bathroom? You haven''t earned those privileges as an APP at Mayo. Oh, and by the way, you can create all the revenue you''d like with your full schedule, charging almost the same as the physician does and getting paid a quarter of that, but you are also not allowed to park in the garage. So you, Physician Assistant or Nurse Practitioner, can park out in Timbuktoo in the middle of whatever weather elements there may be and walk about a quarter of a mile a day to get to work while the physicians park in their designated spots in the garage, and get there after you do and you''ve seen their first patient.','PAs are treated like medical assistants','It''s so convoluted I don''t even know where to start. Besides, much like the employee surveys, they don''t care or do anything about the comments anyway.','The pay
