	 ('2016-04-06T19:20:53.290',1,'NO_OPINION','NEGATIVE',6,2,0,1,'NEGATIVE',2,4,'Mayo Clinic',1,4,'REGULAR',NULL,'Labor and Delivery Nurse','Las Vegas, Nevada','The pay
Potential resume builder
Pension (if you really want to work here for 30 years)
I''m supposed to write 20 words, hopefully this is now enough...','PAs, as well as ARNPs, are expected to know as much as the Physicians, however are treated like we are the bottom of the totem pole. So we are good enough to do the seeing of their patients, assess, diagnose, treat, etc etc, but then when it comes to doing all the scut work, that is also our job. We are not treated with the appropriate amount of respect when it comes to anything, other than being trusted to (depended on to) do all of the patient care. But then when a patient needs to be called for a simple message (secretary or MA task), your patients vitals need to be taken (an MA task), something needs to be faxed (secretary task), a form needs to be entered in the computer (MA, CNA, or secretary task): the PA or NP is also supposed to do also do all of that. So basically, mayo sees all "APP''s" (as they like to call us) as first year residents who the Physicians can unload all of their work on to, as well as can be used for clerical and any other task that needs doing. If you are a PA or an ARNP and are thinking of joining Mayo, keep in mind you will have no ancillary staff to help you, as is the case in the rest of the non-Mayo world. You are the ancillary staff, in addition to being expected to keep a full calendar of patients. Get ready for zero respect from the physicians. If you happen to go in to a surgical subspecialty, you will be delighted to see that between getting to the hospital at 6 am to "pre-round" on all of the surgeons patients before he/she gets there (read: pretty much do everything for the surgeon while he/she is either sleeping or in the "consultants only" lounge, rounding, getting to the OR before the surgeon, doing the assisting in the case, helping at the end of the case, prepping for the next case (it is now 2:00pm), you are not allowed in the surgeons lounge. The surgeon, and whatever other consultant who may chose to also accompany him or her, is free to grab whatever free snack and water or juice and watch some TV while you hold your pee and prep for the next case. Eating? Resting? Going to the bathroom? You haven''t earned those privileges as an APP at Mayo. Oh, and by the way, you can create all the revenue you''d like with your full schedule, charging almost the same as the physician does and getting paid a quarter of that, but you are also not allowed to park in the garage. So you, Physician Assistant or Nurse Practitioner, can park out in Timbuktoo in the middle of whatever weather elements there may be and walk about a quarter of a mile a day to get to work while the physicians park in their designated spots in the garage, and get there after you do and you''ve seen their first patient.','PAs are treated like medical assistants','It''s so convoluted I don''t even know where to start. Besides, much like the employee surveys, they don''t care or do anything about the comments anyway.','The pay

	 ('2022-05-21T03:32:40.070',2,'DISAPPROVE','NEUTRAL',7,1,1,1,NULL,1,4,'Mayo Clinic',1,1,NULL,NULL,'Advanced Practice Registered Nurse','Austin, Texas','New young team, good pay and quick delivery of quality laptop and remote working tools','Mayo Clinic is a dumpster fire.

Executive leadership can''t agree, so basic questions like "What platform are we going to build on?" and "Who owns the final say?" are political landmines. There were essentially 3 projects cannibalising each other and no one corrected the issue.

During onboarding I was told from two different people that they nearly lost their jobs for expressing an idea. After my boss was suddenly fired, I learned they''d gone through 6 bosses in about a year! The executive shrugged it off as a need for "another reorg."

Mayo is a company at war with itself. Everyone that actually tries to help them bring about the change that they say they want gets fired.

Not uncommon to old enterprises, every decision is made by committee. This company is so overly top heavy that when they fired my boss they hired two people to replace her. Immediately the quality of leadership went downhill. 

In this environment where the major concern expressed at every practice meeting is the need for anonymity so there''s no backlash for honest feedback, the next manager that came in was immediately toxic. 

On day 3 she aggressively belittled a vendor for their work, and when the project owners defended it she doubled down and a bunch of emergency leadership meetings were called. Then this lady said it looked bad that the project leaders weren''t willing to come in for this meeting on a religious holiday. That''s religious discrimination plain and simple! 

I watched as leaders said they got rid of people for "icky behavior" but then they were the one''s i saw being toxic and contradicting themselves.

I was partnered with a researcher whose work was extremely junior and when she asked me for feedback, she was always offended by it. I spent hours helping her with basic technology, like Word! I didn''t want to say anything because I didn''t want to get her fired.  After months of abuse from her, I finally spoke up to leadership and they coddled her. 

I looked up both the new manager and the researcher in LinkedIn and both had keyword stuffed their profiles. Which made so much sense, because their contributions to meetings was laughable. Neither the researcher nor the manager could answer basic questions about the project or the platform, and I or others had to jump in and clarify or answer for them.

I started applying for other jobs 5 months into my 1 year contract.','Poor Leadership','Designate single owner of decisions for projects early.

INSERT INTO public.healthcare (reviewdatetime,ratingoverall,ratingceo,ratingbusinessoutlook,ratingworklifebalance,ratingcultureandvalues,ratingdiversityandinclusion,ratingseniorleadership,ratingrecommendtofriend,ratingcareeropportunities,ratingcompensationandbenefits,employer,iscurrentjob,lengthofemployment,employmentstatus,jobendingyear,jobtitle,"location",pros,cons,summary,advice,feedback,polarity_score,feedback_pos,feedback_neg) VALUES
	 ('2013-02-21T17:35:42.060',1,'DISAPPROVE','NEGATIVE',6,2,0,1,'NEGATIVE',2,4,'Mayo Clinic',1,20,'REGULAR',NULL,'Labor and Delivery Nurse','Hudson,   Florida','Mayo Clinic in the historic sense beams excellence.  Incredible minds and technology have been developed here.  Not too long ago that intellect and zeal were almost palpable in what could more-or-less be called the crown jewel of the city of Rochester.  I was honored to continue these traditions through my work and dedication at a place in aesthetics, aptitude, and psyche was an example for the medical community. _x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo Clinic offers excellent compensation for your time and very competitive benefits.  Its one of the few places I have worked at that still offers a pension, affordable medical insurance, several weeks of vacation upon starting, and decent lateral movement should you want to do so.  _x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo once offered a foundation by which you could make life long plans and aspirations.','So what happened?_x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo Clinic for the last few decades has continuously degraded by mediocrity, preferential treatment, poor implementation, ghost riding, and lack of vision. Mayo has been riding on the ghosts of its accomplished past._x000d_
_x000d_
A career at Mayo Clinic is an enigmatic one.  On one side of the coin you will be enthralled to work with able minded people who are not only skillful in the craft of science but who legitimately have passion for patient centered research and care.  I have had the pleasure of seeing people with drive who have worked from the ground up from a simple technician to become an administrator or even Ph. D, as I am currently working on.  The other side of the coin includes select consultants, senior/middle management, and even mid/low level scientists seem to think that once you get your “Golden Ticket” to Mayo you simply put your heart and mind into neutral and coast to maintain the status quo.  There are many wallflowers that only care about the bottom line: their paycheck or personal status._x000d_
_x000d_
While Mayo Clinic fosters brilliant and effective minds, there are just as many if not more that are busy waiving their “Golden Tickets.”  My time has been plagued with a few pampered consultants who verbally and psychologically abuse you, entitled management who are woefully under-equipped in wisdom/aptitude, and salaried/hourly technologists who get away with harassment or being paid for flat out not contributing.  You may as well not report incidences like these, since at any rung of the aforementioned nothing will change.  Rocking the boat puts you at risk for retaliation, ridicule, being overlooked for a promotion, etc._x000d_
_x000d_
The current status of Mayo Clinic would be as one of my colleagues put it, “…we have too many chiefs and not enough Indians.”  When you answer to many people, some of who may be inept or incommunicado with their own contemporaries, avoidable mistakes are made, inefficiencies continue to build, decisions that may be completely dangerous to patient care are created, and the overall mission of Mayo Clinic, “…the needs of the patient come first,” continue to diminish.  At the end of the day the blame is usually assigned to the easiest target or those too meek to defend themselves._x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo’s initial answer to the economic environment in 2008 was lethargic.  Excessive spending on parties, other frivolity, and business as usual continued.  Fast forward to 2013 and Mayo is virtually in a panic over cost control due to being overextended at the cost of morale of its employees and patients.  Benefits large and small continue to shrink or have disappeared completely.  Forward thinking and preparing for fiscal pumps in the road, not banking on changes in philanthropic donations, having MML be fiercely competitive with other health systems, ceasing kingdom building projects, etc. were not a part of the equation until lately.  _x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo is finally starting to take the punch bowl from its own party.  The problem is that while Mayo has been partying for the last 20 years the competition has become a lot smarter and leaner, where Mayo has become slow due to its own convoluted bureaucracy and over indulgence.  The withdrawals are very hard everyone especially for those that actually work very hard, since those perks were the things keeping the talent here. _x000d_
_x000d_
In the years I have been here I have seen magnificent individuals of all levels of employment be crushed by the current of “Mother Mayo’s” will.  When your lifestyle depends on who writes your paycheck, you always see the zombie like following of Mayo either too scared, too indoctrinated, or too burnt out to care to resist the crumbling paradigm that is the psyche of Mayo Clinic.','What happened?','Its time to cut the fat.  Mayo is the only place of employ I have had that has so many management staff and such an overly complicated bureaucracy.  Hold people accountable.  It doesn''t matter if it is a consultant or custodian, if they perpetually abuse colleagues or "the system" pull the plug to make room for those that will be the envy of other health care systems.  Isn''t that what Mayo is supposed to be about?  We need passion and talent.  We need to do everything we can to keep employees motivated not complacent.  We need to do all of this while keeping our ability to do so simple along with putting the patient numbero uno.','Mayo Clinic in the historic sense beams excellence.  Incredible minds and technology have been developed here.  Not too long ago that intellect and zeal were almost palpable in what could more-or-less be called the crown jewel of the city of Rochester.  I was honored to continue these traditions through my work and dedication at a place in aesthetics, aptitude, and psyche was an example for the medical community. _x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo Clinic offers excellent compensation for your time and very competitive benefits.  Its one of the few places I have worked at that still offers a pension, affordable medical insurance, several weeks of vacation upon starting, and decent lateral movement should you want to do so.  _x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo once offered a foundation by which you could make life long plans and aspirations.. So what happened?_x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo Clinic for the last few decades has continuously degraded by mediocrity, preferential treatment, poor implementation, ghost riding, and lack of vision. Mayo has been riding on the ghosts of its accomplished past._x000d_
_x000d_
A career at Mayo Clinic is an enigmatic one.  On one side of the coin you will be enthralled to work with able minded people who are not only skillful in the craft of science but who legitimately have passion for patient centered research and care.  I have had the pleasure of seeing people with drive who have worked from the ground up from a simple technician to become an administrator or even Ph. D, as I am currently working on.  The other side of the coin includes select consultants, senior/middle management, and even mid/low level scientists seem to think that once you get your “Golden Ticket” to Mayo you simply put your heart and mind into neutral and coast to maintain the status quo.  There are many wallflowers that only care about the bottom line: their paycheck or personal status._x000d_
_x000d_
While Mayo Clinic fosters brilliant and effective minds, there are just as many if not more that are busy waiving their “Golden Tickets.”  My time has been plagued with a few pampered consultants who verbally and psychologically abuse you, entitled management who are woefully under-equipped in wisdom/aptitude, and salaried/hourly technologists who get away with harassment or being paid for flat out not contributing.  You may as well not report incidences like these, since at any rung of the aforementioned nothing will change.  Rocking the boat puts you at risk for retaliation, ridicule, being overlooked for a promotion, etc._x000d_
_x000d_
The current status of Mayo Clinic would be as one of my colleagues put it, “…we have too many chiefs and not enough Indians.”  When you answer to many people, some of who may be inept or incommunicado with their own contemporaries, avoidable mistakes are made, inefficiencies continue to build, decisions that may be completely dangerous to patient care are created, and the overall mission of Mayo Clinic, “…the needs of the patient come first,” continue to diminish.  At the end of the day the blame is usually assigned to the easiest target or those too meek to defend themselves._x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo’s initial answer to the economic environment in 2008 was lethargic.  Excessive spending on parties, other frivolity, and business as usual continued.  Fast forward to 2013 and Mayo is virtually in a panic over cost control due to being overextended at the cost of morale of its employees and patients.  Benefits large and small continue to shrink or have disappeared completely.  Forward thinking and preparing for fiscal pumps in the road, not banking on changes in philanthropic donations, having MML be fiercely competitive with other health systems, ceasing kingdom building projects, etc. were not a part of the equation until lately.  _x000d_
_x000d_
Mayo is finally starting to take the punch bowl from its own party.  The problem is that while Mayo has been partying for the last 20 years the competition has become a lot smarter and leaner, where Mayo has become slow due to its own convoluted bureaucracy and over indulgence.  The withdrawals are very hard everyone especially for those that actually work very hard, since those perks were the things keeping the talent here. _x000d_
_x000d_

I also learned the differences in working with consultants, residents and fellows, a teaching hospital. Good benefits, nice workout facility.  I saw Mayo Clinic change dramatically. There was a huge difference when the Sisters of St. Francis were managing the hospital, they made sure the patient''s always got excellent care including the details. The hospital has teams for starting IV''s, putting in urinary catheters and drawing labs, as a nurse you can call a team to take care of those things for you.  Excellent consultants if you are lucky enough to see them. All of their facilities are very clean and well organized.','Small but critical things fall through the cracks. Inexperienced Residents are not closely supervised  by the consultants. I have experienced this both as a staff member and as a patient. Medications errors by the MD, and when followed up on are brushed under the rug. Discharge summaries that state that the patient is being discharged with home health or hospice care and the discharge planner or MD have not even consulted with the agency, they just tell the patient to call someone when they get home. Patients feel "pushed out the door". They have discharge planning nurses that have never even seen the patient and are making referrals. The clinic is focused on checklists and procedural guidelines that are written by nurses who have not worked with patients for over 20 years. They actually have a committee on committee''s, lots of wasted time and money with administration and time and money taken away from quality patient care. I was so proud to work for Mayo....it is sad to see the lack of attention to details. Mayo has a lot of resources available, such as phlebotomy, STAR RN (ICU nurse who rounds on critical patients), vascular access team (RNs who do central line dressing changes, place PICCs, access PORTs). The nursing staff who work here are overall very nice and willing to help one another.','COVID has been awful for all hospitals; however, Mayo has not supported their nursing staff throughout the pandemic. They think giving the staff a $500 gift card and offering double pay to pick up additional shifts (for a short amount of time, that you have to schedule two weeks in advance) makes up for not giving us any other incentives for drowning with terrible staffing ratios the past six months. They do not care that we are incredibly short staffed and are having trouble giving patients the care they deserve and expect at Mayo; but, they still have no problem sending individual emails to their staff if something was done wrong. They want to say "the needs of the patient come first" any chance they get, but the truth is, they only care about the bottom line. They have lost their respect and appreciation for their nursing staff and they have made that incredibly obvious throughout COVID. We didn''t expect things to be easy throughout the pandemic and understand staffing may be short, but Mayo was the worst paying hospital in the area and refused to pay their staff anything extra to help retain staff. HCA''s 401K company match changed from monthly to annually. This meant you had to be employed by HCA at the end of the year to see the match reflected in your account by early February of the following year. My husband is active duty (ARMY) and was restationed to another city in Texas. We moved in the summer, and I feel like I missed out on half a year of HCA''s company match due to an uncontrollable life event.
